intro: Aquilegia formosa var. hypolasia, commonly known as the Sierra lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of showy, spurred flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant has palmately divided, compound leaves that are typically hairy and dark green. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, often found in meadows and open woodlands. Its nectar-rich flowers attract a variety of pollinators, including bees and butterflies.
